input: The N.B.A. players union is considering an appeal of the seven-game suspensions given to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson for legal issues. Each player was suspended by the league Saturday without pay and was scheduled to miss the first seven games of next season. Artest would lose a little more than $470,000 in salary, about $50,000 more than Jackson.Jackson released a statement through the Golden State Warriors saying he accepted his suspension. But the union, comparing the penalties with other recent suspensions given to players for off-the-court reasons, may take action. Artest pleaded no contest in May to a misdemeanor domestic violence charge that stemmed from a dispute with his wife on March 5. Jackson pleaded guilty last month to a felony count of criminal recklessness for firing a gun outside an Indianapolis strip club last fall, when he was with the Indiana Pacers. The union has 30 days from Saturday to file an appeal to be heard by an arbitrator.
syn: The N.B.A. players association is contemplating challenging the seven-game bans handed to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson due to legal troubles. Each athlete was penalized by the association on Saturday, leading to a suspension from the first seven matchups of the following season without compensation. Artest stands to forfeit slightly over $470,000 in earnings, approximately $50,000 more than Jackson. Through the Golden State Warriors, Jackson stated he was in agreement with his suspension. However, the union, after reviewing other recent disciplinary actions for similar off-the-field incidents, might protest. Artest entered a no contest plea in May to a misdemeanor charge of domestic violence arising from a confrontation with his spouse on March 5. Last month, Jackson admitted guilt to a criminal recklessness felony for discharging a firearm outside a strip club in Indianapolis the previous autumn, during his time with the Indiana Pacers. The association has a 30-day window from Saturday to submit an appeal that would be evaluated by an arbitrator.

syn: The National Basketball Association's players association is contemplating an appeal concerning the seven-game bans handed to Ron Artest and Stephen Jackson due to legal matters. Artest stands to forfeit slightly over $470,000 in earnings, which is around $50,000 more than what Jackson is set to lose. Though Jackson, through a statement from the Golden State Warriors, has acknowledged his suspension, the association, by examining these sanctions in light of other recent disciplinary actions for conduct outside the court, is pondering over taking steps. In May, Artest admitted to a lesser charge of domestic abuse after an altercation with his spouse on March 5. Last month, Jackson acknowledged guilt to a serious charge of criminal recklessness for discharging a firearm near a strip club in Indianapolis the previous autumn, during his tenure with the Indiana Pacers. The association has a month from Saturday to lodge an appeal, which would then be reviewed by an arbitrator.

input: ATHENS -- There's an unwritten rule in team travel in basketball. On the bus, the coach sits in the first seat up front, well away from the players. On the US women's team bus, the coach, Van Chancellor, sits in the back. He plays cards with his players. They say he cheats. He says they lie.

He claims they are not telling the truth.

input: Jon Robert Holden scored with two seconds remaining in Madrid to lift Russia over Spain, 60-59, in the European Championship final. Holden stripped the ball from the Spanish center Pau Gasol, then pump-faked before his jump shot bounced high and in for the victory. Gasol’s jumper at the buzzer rattled out as time expired. Andrei Kirilenko, the tournament’s most valuable player, had 17 points as the Russians earned their first European title since they won as the Soviet Union 22 years ago. Holden, who has dual American and Russian citizenship, played for Bucknell from 1994-98.
syn: Jon Robert Holden hit the game-winning basket with just two seconds left in Madrid, propelling Russia past Spain, 60-59, in the EuroBasket final. Holden stole the ball from Spanish center Pau Gasol, then executed a pump-fake before his jump shot ricocheted high and went in for the win. Gasol’s attempt at the buzzer missed as time ran out. Andrei Kirilenko, named the tournament’s MVP, scored 17 points as the Russians claimed their inaugural European championship since their last victory as the Soviet Union 22 years prior. Holden, possessing both American and Russian nationality, was a player for Bucknell from 1994 to 1998.

input: Jon Robert Holden scored with two seconds remaining in Madrid to lift Russia over Spain, 60-59, in the European Championship final. input: Forbes.com - Mickey Mouse may be 75, but age hasn't put a damper on his earning power. Last year Mickey and Disney pals Minnie, Donald, Daisy, Pluto and Goofy grossed $5.8 billion from toys, movies and the like. That's 23% more than the year before, when Disney's Winnie the Pooh topped the list. Why the mouse's rebound? Credit hoopla and new products--including adult apparel--tied to Mickey's milestone birthday last year. For more details, stories and methodology, go to forbes.com/extra.
syn: Mickey Mouse might be 75, but his age hasn't slowed down his financial success. Last year, Mickey along with Disney friends Minnie, Donald, Daisy, Pluto, and Goofy earned $5.8 billion from merchandise, films, and similar sources. That's a 23% increase over the previous year, when Disney's Winnie the Pooh was at the top of the earnings list. What's behind the mouse's resurgence? Attribute it to the excitement and new offerings—including clothing for adults—connected to Mickey's significant anniversary the prior year. For additional information, stories, and the approach used, visit forbes.com/extra.

input: OSLO, Norway - Armed, masked thieves burst into a lightly guarded Oslo museum Sunday and snatched the Edvard Munch masterpiece "The Scream" and a second Munch painting from the walls as stunned visitors watched in shock. input: If you hang around on web-related mailing lists long enough, you start getting the idea that the future is full of metadata. Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.
syn:
If you spend enough time on web-related discussion forums, you eventually get the sense that the future is overflowing with metadata. This metadata might or might not be XML, or it could or couldn't be RDF or OWL or several other technologies with impressive terms like “ontology” included in their names. It could or couldn't be the long-envisioned (and frequently mocked) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it might or might not involve a variety of buzzwords, and it could or couldn't be beneficial. However, one thing is certain: the future will surely be laden with metadata; on this, the specialists concur.

To me, there’s an issue with this: the debate often relies on technologies that either don’t yet exist or aren't fully developed, leading it to perpetually speculate about how things will improve “in the future,” a time that might never arrive. Fortunately, there’s a straightforward method to inject plenty of metadata into your content immediately, without needing to master anything more complex than the reliable HTML 4.01. If this becomes widespread, “the future” might arrive much earlier than anticipated.

Now, this metadata may or may not be XML, or it may or may not be RDF or OWL or a dozen other technologies with impressive-sounding words like “ontology” in their names. It may or may not be the long-dreamt-of (and often derided) “Semantic Web.” In fact, it may or may not be a dozen different buzzwords, and it may or may not be a good thing. But whatever the future is, it will definitely be full of metadata; on this the experts agree.    To my mind there’s a problem with this: the argument always seems to depend on technologies which don’t exist or aren’t quite ready yet, so it always falls back to talking about how things will be “in the future,” which may never get here. Luckily, there's an easy way to add oodles of metadata to your documents right this minute, without having to learn anything more complicated than trusty old HTML 4.01. If it catches on, “the future” might get here a lot sooner than expected.

input: WASHINGTON - Companies added 96,000 jobs to their payrolls in September, fewer than economists forecast for the last employment report before Election Day, highlighting a modest pace of hiring that has become an issue in President Bush's bid for another term.    The four hurricanes striking Florida and other coastal states the past two months "appears to have held down employment growth, but not enough to change (the overall jobs picture) materially," the Labor Department said Friday in assessing September's national employment situation...
syn: WASHINGTON - Corporations incorporated 96,000 positions into their workforce in September, which was less than what economists had anticipated for the final jobs report before Election Day, underscoring a moderate hiring rate that has become a topic in President Bush's reelection campaign. The four storms hitting Florida and other coastal regions in the previous two months "seems to have restrained job growth, but not sufficiently to alter (the overall employment landscape) significantly," the Labor Department reported Friday in evaluating September's nationwide employment conditions.

The four hurricanes striking Florida and other coastal states the past two months "appears to have held down employment growth, but not enough to change (the overall jobs picture) materially," the Labor Department said Friday in assessing September's national employment situation...
